channel.title: Projects on Hector Roux de Bézieux
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Hector Roux de Bézieux

item.title: Dune
item.description: Improving replicability in single-cell RNA-Seq cell type discovery with Dune Work in collaboration with Kelly Street, Stephan Fischer, Koen Van den Berge, Rebecca Chance, Davide Risso, Jesse Gillis, John Ngai, Elizabeth Purdom, Sandrine Dudoit. Abstract: Single-cell transcriptome sequencing (scRNA-Seq) has allowed many new types of investigations at unprecedented and unique levels of resolution. Among the primary goals of scRNA-Seq is the classification of cells into potentially novel cell types. Many approaches build on the existing clustering literature to develop tools specific to single-cell applications.

item.title: ESCAPE
item.description: ESCAPE Easy Single-Cell RNA-sequencing Analyis through a Political Example Single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) is a very potent biological tool used for many applications. A far from exhaustive list would include identifying new cell types, finding differentially expressed (DE) genes, and discovering lineages among cells. To get an overview of the principle, see here. However, the usual framework might seem a little daunting for beginners and, while many well-crafted tutorials exists, they all share the same idea: use a biological dataset as an example.

item.title: R Package used for my useful functions
item.description: This is a package to load useful functions that I use on a daily basis. It also contains a template for an Rmd and RStudio Project template. The package website is available at https://hectorrdb.github.io/DailyHRB/. You can install it from Github with the following: if (!"devtools" %in% installed.packages()) { install.pacakges("devtools") } devtools::install_github("HectorRDB/DailyHRB") or from source with git clone git@github.com:HectorRDB/DailyHRB.git R CMD INSTALL DailyHRB

item.title: CS289 Final Project
item.description: Modelization of single-cell gene expression along a timeline Report abstract The explosion of genomic data over the past two decades created a need for new and more performing tools. One type of data in particular, Single-cell RNA Sequencing data, allow for a cell-level detection of biological patterns but technical limitations add lots of noise sources to the data. In particular, some counts are dropped and appear as zeros, even thought the gene is expressed in the cell.

item.title: Courses taken at UC Berkeley
item.description: 2019 2018 2017 2019 PB HLTH 290: Targeted Learning with Biomedical Big Data with Mark Van der Laan Final Project Proposal on Overleaf 2018 CMPBIO 293 Doctoral Seminar in Computational Biology (Spring) with Nir Yosef Presentation 1 Presentation 2 CMPBIO 293 Doctoral Seminar in Computational Biology (Fall) with Priya Moorjani & Daniel Rokhsar Presentation STAT 210A Theoretical Statistics with Will Fithian STAT 215B Statistical Models: Theory and Application with Jon Mcauliffe Final Project not public STAT 248 Analysis of Time Series with David Brillinger Final Project report and code CS 298A Introduction to Machine Learning with Jennifer Listgarten and Anant Sahai Final Project CS 294 Machine Learning and Statistics Meet Biology with Jennifer Listgarten Presentation Final Project report.

item.title: STAT 215A: Labs
item.description: STAT 215A Statistical Models: Theory and Application I took this class in the Fall 2017, with Bin Yu and Rebecca Barter. For the purpose of this class, we studied 3 datasets across 4 labs. The grading was partly peer-reviewed based so my github for this class contains works from other students that I cannot share. However, the lab reports and code files are below: Lab 1: Redwood trees Lab 2: Linguistic Survey Lab 3: Linguistic Survey Stability Lab 4: Cloud detection Report Lab1 Lab2 Lab3 Lab4 Code Lab1 Lab2 Lab3 Lab4 Likewise, for the final report, the project report and code are accessible.

item.title: Welcome to the RNA-Seq world
item.description: Overview Recently, Philippe Boileau joined the Dudoit lab and I had to think on which resources to point him to so that he could start getting up to speed with on the field. Together, we hence build the following list of interesting material. Those fall into 4 broad (and largely overlapping) categories: How to produce data with sequencing How to find, access and pre-process data (including how to use bio-informatics tools) How to analyze the data: statistics How to use all of the above to conduct an analysis (with - of course - a strong emphasis on R tools) How to do all those analyses correctly: reproducible research I’ll therefore try to list resources to help in all subjects.

item.title: tradeSeq
item.description: tradeSeq: Trajectory-based differential expression analysis for single-cell sequencing data Work in collaboration with Koen Van den Berge, Kelly Street, Wouter Saelens, Robrecht Cannoodt, Yvan Saeys, Sandrine Dudoit and Lieven Clement Abstract: Trajectory inference has radically enhanced single-cell RNA-seq research by enabling the study of dynamic changes in gene expression. Downstream of trajectory inference, it is vital to discover genes that are (i) associated with the lineages in the trajectory, or (ii) differentially expressed between lineages, to illuminate the underlying biological processes.
